response.answer_text: Before Einstein work e=mc^2, things are mass.After Einstein work, things are energy and mass.People expects that things will never disappear. If in the future, science find out a case that energy disappears like mass transfers into energy, it transfers into another form X, then things are energy, mass and X. From the view of Taoism, things are children of Tao. But the Tao is so vast and undefinable (The Tao that can be completely explained or expressed with spoken words is not the constant, eternally unchanging and true Tao.) My opinion is that things are existence that is governed by Tao, not our mind. Some examples: Is language “thing”: yes, by writing it out the marked on paper expressed it, by speaking it out the sound expressed language and silence thinking, our brain stimulus results in chemical reaction in our mind. (You can find more: The Feral Child Nicknamed Genie).Is information “thing”: yes, information is transferred via signal. Without signal, that information is lost, for example a broken pins memory card. Signal has its form of energy, electric, magnetic or optical.Is ‘Doraemon’ thing: no, just a model of its is thing, for example a Doraemon puppet, a Doraemon doll.

“Things” in dialectical philosophy are finite objects with a birth date, a specific duration, and an expiration date. All “things” are finite — by definition. Some “things” — e.g. the botanical and biological — reproduce before they expire. As long as “things” exist in time, they occupy some degree of space. All “things” exist in a spatial and temporal relationship to all other “things.” As spatial entities, all “things” tend to be three-dimensional, so that to examine each “thing” requires that we “turn” them this way and that way — that we “tour” them. While we look upon one side of a “thing,” we cannot see the other side of the “thing.” “Things” can have many other relationships with other “things.” And so on.
